column4: I'm trying to upgrade a machine from dapper to feisty. apt-get seems to have got itself in a twist. When I run apt-get -f install it is trying to install "metacity" *and* "metacity-common", which try to install the same files and it dies with an error.
How can I tell it not to install one of them?
good luck.  Those were six or seven hours I'd like back-- I did it on two boxes last week.  Try the -f option.  I was able to finally pull out of errors between that command and updating
thanks. I am using the -f option though.
let me go through my bash history for the apt commands I ran.  brb
Ooo-- I think I *may* possibly have a solution
I think that would be a good word for it :)

okay, I have told it to uninstall everything that depends on metacity, and everything that depends on that, and so on, by hand until they're all gone... and now it's finishing installing everything else
then I'll put them back when it's done
like when you hunt for two days to see why BIND doesn't work, only to find an extra semicolon or some such
I'm working on a paste by the way
try having a look at these.  http://rafb.net/p/2J4fWe34.html
thos eare in no particular order
